div1.head: The Finca San Jose, by Philip Showalter Hench, [September 1940]
div1.p:
The Pedroso family is one of the oldest and most illustrious in
Cuba. During the entire (Spanish) Colonial period of Cuba
members of the Pedroso family held high positions in the social
and political life of Havana. The manorial “Pedroso
Palace” which faces the waterfront (address:
de Pedroso y Florencia) was built in 1770 by Don Matheo
de Pedroso y Florencia (who had been Mayor of Havana in 1750)
and was occupied by his family, widow (Dona Mariana
Barreto) and descendants until it was rented in 1840 to
the illustrious patrician Don Juan Montalvo y O'Farrill.

Other property owned by the Pedroso family included
the Finca San Jose in the Havana suburb, Quemados de
Marianas. I do not know just when the Finca San Jose
was purchased by the Pedroso family but they owned the
Finca from the middle of the 18th century; thus the Finca San
Jose has been in the hands of the Pedroso family for
about 200 years (1750-1950 ??).

The oldest available map of the Finca San Jose
(framed and hanging in 1941 in the town home of Senora
Rojas) is dated 1857 (I have copy) shows that the
present residence (and the fence in front of it) facing Calzada
Real existed as early as 1857. (When was the house built?).
The fence is of masonry, a mixture (much used formerly)
of rocks of all sizes, earth and clay covered with adobe.

The original Finca San Jose comprised about 100
acres ( ). For along period (from
1750- ?) the land was unoccupied. In the near
of the property was limestone and about _____
the stone began to be quarried. A limekiln and the
stone quarry were operated “from the year 1857” and the
help of negro slaves and chinese. The quarry and
limekiln were leased by the Pedroso family during the
years to various lessees; for example they (and the
residence) were leased to Dr. Colleja and Brother from _____ to
July 31, 1900.

From about 1873 to 1884 or 1885, (for about 11 years) the
Finca San Jose with its residence was leased to the Jesuit
priests (from nearby Belin college?) who used it (as a
summer residence? Did they use it all year? For what
purpose?) according to Dr C E Finlay, p. 82, the Jesuits
sent their non-immune members to the residence on the
Finca San Jose during the summer months. During there 11
years not a single case of yellow fever developed among
the whole residents of the Finca San Jose, a fact commented
upon by Dr. Chaille in his report of the American Yellow Fever
Commission which visited Havana in 1879.

Presumably deserted between 1898 and 1900 the Finca San Jose was
used of the Military Health Officer of its American army
(get dates; for what purposes? See Rojas entry of Nov 15, 1900)

div1.p:
Dr Carlos Finlay's began hisfirst inoculation - experiments in June 1881.
were made in 1881 on soldiers and other volunteers in Havana.
He continued his experiments in 1883; the first 2 volunteers of
this series were non-immune Jesuit priests who were
living at the Finca San Jose; one of these was Father
urra who developed yellow fever on Aug 26, 1883. “None
of the other non-immunes (Jesuits) who were stopping at the
farm contracted the disease” (C. E. Finlay, p 82).

(Shortly after this (exactly when? ______) the Jesuits
closed their lease on the San Jose Farm & leased La as a
“pleasure farm”, La Asuncion, in Luyans, 10 miles
from Havana. Here Finlay carried on further experiments
on Jesuit volunteers.)
